repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Support pickling of CyFunctions.

Will eventually close #2584

Follows the scheme outlines in the comments of that issue. I'm using the function cname as the key (because I believe it should be unique).

Currently known to not be working are:
* fused functions (except for a few select very trivial cases)
* any function with a classobj - although it isn't easy to generate these in a closure in a way that's ever likely to be useful.
* any function with non-trivial defaults - this requires a fairly substantial change to how defaults are stored, which I think isn't needed for the initial implementation.
* Running generators and any generator expressions (would need a separate type of be changed)

All of these cases fail fairly gracefully so I'm not planning to deal with them here.

comment_data.body: I have a feeling that `is_x` should only be `True` or `False` and if we want to represent more states then it should not be in `is_x` pattern

             code.putln("new((void*)&(p->%s)) %s();" % (
                 entry.cname, decl_code))
 
+        if scope.is_internal == 2 and py_attrs:

comment_data.body: now that we have three states, we cannot say that `it is set` (i.e., `is_internal == True`), but we must say something like `is_internal == 1 ... `

                 code.putln("#endif")
-            if not type.scope.is_internal and not type.scope.directives.get('internal'):
-                # scope.is_internal is set for types defined by
+            if not type.scope.internal_mode and not type.scope.directives.get('internal'):

                 # Cython (such as closures), the 'internal'
                 # directive is set by users

comment_data.body: I think it would be better to use enum (or at least strings) to indicate the state
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1592,13 +1593,23 @@ def generate_new_function(self, scope, code, cclass_entry):
             code.putln("new((void*)&(p->%s)) %s();" % (
                 entry.cname, decl_code))
 
+        if scope.internal_mode == 2 and py_attrs:
+            # create a hybrid "optional initialization" where the kwds
+            # argument is used to signal that initialization happens.
+            # This is needed for pickleable closures, where the attributes
+            # need to be uninitialized when created in functions (to match
+            # existing behaviour) but initialized when unpickling (to
+            # avoid segfaults decrefing NULL)
+            code.putln("if (k) {")
         for entry in py_attrs:
             if entry.name == "__dict__":
                 needs_error_cleanup = True
                 code.put("p->%s = PyDict_New(); if (unlikely(!p->%s)) goto bad;" % (
                     entry.cname, entry.cname))
             else:
                 code.put_init_var_to_py_none(entry, "p->%s", nanny=False)
+        if scope.internal_mode == 2 and py_attrs:
+            code.putln("}")

comment_data.body:
> but we can use the enum34 backport!

No. I think we try quite hard not to require extra dependencies. So while I like enums it isn't worth adding a dependency for that.

comment_data.body:
> I think we try quite hard not to require extra dependencies.

Is there any reason for this? If our code is cleaner and limits unnecessary freedom, then the quality of the product itself will improve.

Not to mention the fact that we can probably refuse to support running cython itself on python 2.7, while still allowing compilation for this version.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body:
This PR isn't really the place to debate this so I'll reply once and then leave the topic, but:

> Is there any reason for this? If our code is cleaner and limits unnecessary freedom, then the quality of the product itself will improve.

Adding dependencies would Cython harder to install (you can no longer tell users "just install Cython"...), you have to track versions for dependencies (have they changed and broken anything, is it a problem if users have another a different version installed?), and you can't necessarily control the dependencies they bring in. Of course it's a trade-off and there's definitely advantages to using good code written elsewhere, but for something like Cython that's a dependency of a lot of other stuff there's a big advantage to having very minimal decisions. (Of course, this wasn't my decision when it was originally made, and I can't know all the motivations of the people who made it...)

> Not to mention the fact that we can probably refuse to support running cython itself on python 2.7, while still allowing compilation for this version.

That's probably as good as dropping support entirely: if I want a Cython module compiling with a specific version of Python I call `pythonx.x setup.py ...`, or `cythonize-x.x` (which uses that version of Python), or use a Jupyter notebook with that version of Python. Of course it's possible to do the steps separately but it's hard and most people don't.

+        if scope.internal_mode == 2 and py_attrs:
+            # create a hybrid "optional initialization" where the kwds
+            # argument is used to signal that initialization happens.
+            # This is needed for pickleable closures, where the attributes
+            # need to be uninitialized when created in functions (to match
+            # existing behaviour) but initialized when unpickling (to
+            # avoid segfaults decrefing NULL)

         for entry in py_attrs:

                     entry.cname, entry.cname))
             else:
                 code.put_init_var_to_py_none(entry, "p->%s", nanny=False)
+        if scope.internal_mode == 2 and py_attrs:
+            code.putln("}")

comment_data.body:
> This PR isn't really the place to debate this

True, but where is that place?

> Of course it's possible to do the steps separately but it's hard and most people don't.

I think it's the matter of giving the users such mechanism.
Like with the `ast.parse` (`feature_version` argument), we can just apply different rules and restrictions depending on the versions for what we compile.
I don't know how long it will take to end support for python 2, it seems to me long enough to create an artificial support mechanism for compiling for earlier versions.

There may be some caveats with compiling for python 2 with the library of python 3, but we can either request the presence of the python 2 files, or (the better but longer/harder way) just simulate or copypaste some implementation details, that are not present in python 3

comment_data.body:
> > This PR isn't really the place to debate this
> 
> True, but where is that place?

The cython-devel mailing list. But please don't ask for this specific addition as I would only reject it.

> Not to mention the fact that we can probably refuse to support running cython itself on python 2.7, while still allowing compilation for this version.

This would make Cython substantially more difficult to install and test. Also not up for discussion right now. Py2.7 support will be removed in Cython 3.1, so there is no need to even think about this.

comment_data.body:
I've replaced it with a `needs_pickleable_closure_constructor` flag and reverted `is_internal` back to its original use. Hopefully that's clear, if verbose.

(I think the `is_internal` flag always did more than the user `@cython.internal` option though and is only used for closure scopes)

commit.message:
Expanded reduce function for cyfunction

It still requires a bunch of initialization of the Cython side
Make closure classes pickleable if possible
Closured class optionally initializes Python members

Excluded genexprs somewhat

They don't work yet and they cause issues.
Also hid internal scope

Avoid creating a new FusedFunction on class lookup

Among other things this makes it pickleable by ensuring
that it's the same object each time
Fused functions works as well as they can for now
Hopefully fixed most of the tests

Changed representation of is_internal

(None was a little awkward to work with)
Handle pickleable funcs in utility code

More testsuite bugfixes

One missing attribute on compiled ParseTreeTransforms
Exclude Python 3.4 from some tests
Exclude limited API

commit.message:
Move lookup to dict and switch

Instead of many string comparisons. I think this'll be a bit more
optimized

Handle platforms where sizeof(funcptr) != sizeof(void*)

Fixes #4683

It's mostly a theoretical concern I think, but may apply to
some "not too obscure" platforms (ia64?).

For the majority of platforms it keeps working as before (copies
the function pointer into the void* of a capsule) although I've
used memcpy rather than a union to do this (because I don't
believe the union trick is 100% guaranteed to work in standard
c++, although practically it does of course).

For any where this doesn't apply it allocates memory instead and
the capsule points to that.

My interest in this is to use when pickling CyFunctions, but this
PR just uses the mechanism for cimporting cdef functions

Undid changes to "ImportExport"

they're really part of a separate PR

commit.message:
Let the functionpickling utility code come at the end

Since it needs access to all the C function pointers defined in
earlier Cython code.

title: Pickle CyFunctions
